dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so I was just reading this report, and, uh, you are not going to believe the "joyous news" from New York Life's 2018 survey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so I was just reading this report, and, uh, you are not going to believe the joyous news from New York Life's twenty eighteen survey.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats the sobering news from New York Lifes 2018 Life Insurance Gap Survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, joyous? Is it about, like, free lattes for everyone? Or perhaps, you know, student loan forgiveness?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, joyous? Is it about, like, free lattes for everyone? Or perhaps, you know, student loan forgiveness?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Even better, apparently! Millennials are just *overflowing* with life insurance. Like, an average of $100,000 in protection. Far exceeding their needs, mind you.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even better, apparently! Millennials are just overflowing with life insurance. Like, an average of one hundred thousand dollars in protection. Far exceeding their needs, mind you.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials with life insurance have an average of $100,000 in life insurance protection in place, enough to cover one fifth (22%) of their self-reported coverage needs of $452,000. Thats a coverage shortfall of $352,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs] Wait, so *over-insured* is "joyous news" now? I thought, like, more is always better?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so over-insured is joyous news now? I thought, like, more is always better?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it gets better. According to Brian Madgett from New York Life, it’s not that they *want* life insurance. It’s that they are "compelled by law to invest it."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it gets better. According to Brian Madgett from New York Life, it's not that they want life insurance. It's that they are compelled by law to invest it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not an issue of Millennials not wanting to get life insurance; its more a prioritization issue, says Brian Madgett, who leads New York Lifes national life sales and its advanced planning group.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Compelled? You mean like, *forced*? Like a mandatory investment?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Compelled? You mean like, forced? Like a mandatory investment?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! He says young people can't even buy a big-screen TV, a car, or even that daily cup of coffee without showing proof of having life insurance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! He says young people can't even buy a big-screen T V, a car, or even that daily cup of coffee without showing proof of having life insurance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The concept of taking care of their families and loved ones is in competition with the big screen tv, car and even that daily cup of coffee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. I mean, um, that certainly explains why they’re so flush with policies. So, what's the purpose of this mandatory insurance, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. I mean, um, that certainly explains why they're so flush with policies. So, what's the purpose of this mandatory insurance, then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: To curb student loan debt, believe it or not, and to ensure they spend money on their children's education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: To curb student loan debt, believe it or not, and to ensure they spend money on their children's education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The concept of taking care of their families and loved ones is in competition with the big screen tv, car and even that daily cup of coffee. Not to mention their student loan debtand the desire to save for their childrens education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, because that's the natural progression. And, uh, are other generations similarly, you know, compelled?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, because that's the natural progression. And, uh, are other generations similarly, you know, compelled?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not to the same extent. Millennials, they’re showing a 78% surplus. Gen Xers, like us, um, only a 48% surplus. Baby Boomers have about a 37% extra. Everyone’s just swimming in it!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not to the same extent. Millennials, they're showing a seventy eight percent surplus. Gen Xers, like us, um, only a forty eight percent surplus. Baby Boomers have about a thirty seven percent extra. Everyone's just swimming in it!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials...report a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage... By contrast, Gen Xers...report a 48% coverage shortfall... Baby Boomers say they have $190,000 of coverage but need $300,000a 37% shortfall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what’s this Madgett guy suggesting we do with all this *extra* cash tied up in life insurance?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's this Madgett guy suggesting we do with all this extra cash tied up in life insurance?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He says it's a "call to action for families who are struggling to get rid of their extra cash." Like, "listen up when a family member says, 'I hate having this extra money!'"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He says it's a call to action for families who are struggling to get rid of their extra cash. Like, listen up when a family member says, I hate having this extra money!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Madgett suggests using the life insurance gap data as a conversation starter over the holidays. Listen up when a family member says, Hey, you need to take care of this, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Oh, man. I remember my dad, he actually, uh, made my husband and me get term life policies. We sold ours when we had kids, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, man. I remember my dad, he actually, uh, made my husband and me get term life policies. We sold ours when we had kids, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I remember my dad nudging my husband and me to get term life insurance policies. We finally did when we had kids.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because having a home and kids are, quote, "the two big financial wastes that prompt people to cancel their coverage." [sarcastic tone]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because having a home and kids are, quote, the two big financial wastes that prompt people to cancel their coverage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying a home and having kids are the two big things that prompt people to get coverage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. But then it immediately says you *shouldn't* cancel it, because you won't have enough to replace lost income. Which is it?!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. But then it immediately says you shouldn't cancel it, because you won't have enough to replace lost income. Which is it?!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Get enough insurance to replace the lost income of the deceased, so the surviving spouse can carry on with paying the mortgage and saving for retirement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's confusing! And, uh, it says term life is "expensive," but then gives an example of $250 a year for half a million dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's confusing! And, uh, it says term life is expensive, but then gives an example of two hundred fifty dollars a year for half a million dollars.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right! And don't forget its stellar advice: "do not shop around" and "don't assess the financial strength of the insurance company before you buy."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! And don't forget its stellar advice: do not shop around and don't assess the financial strength of the insurance company before you buy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Premiums vary greatly for the same product from different insurers, so shop around. And make sure you assess the financial strength of the insurance company before you buy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, definitely follow *those* tips, folks! Unbelievable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, definitely follow those tips, folks! Unbelievable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, in summary: Millennials are rich with life insurance, forced to get it, and we should all ignore good advice. Got it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, in summary: Millennials are rich with life insurance, forced to get it, and we should all ignore good advice. Got it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials...report a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage...
